abstract: This Saturday collaboration between Wyna Liu and Joel Fagliano looks hard, but it really just looks hard.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — If a puzzle like this one makes you wonder who makes the rules around here, well, Wyna Liu and Joel Fagliano make up at least 20 percent of The New York Times’s crossword nerve center. Individually, they’re constructors of wide repute, but this is their first collaboration; they had tried before, apparently, but their schedules never lined up. To work around that, they agreed to split things up in an interesting way: Ms. Liu composed an entire clue set, Mr. Fagliano constructed a grid full of peppy entries, and then a neutral party reconciled the two halves.
headline: Cry Heard on April Fools’ Day
keywords: Crossword Puzzles;Fagliano, Joel (Crossword Constructor);Liu, Wyna (Crossword Constructor);APRIL FOOL'S DAY

abstract: George Black’s new book, “The Long Reckoning,” describes the environmental devastation of the Vietnam War.
lead_paragraph: The lore of American military logistics celebrates triumphs of sustainment. Take the Civil War “Cracker Line,” a network of wagon roads and pontoon bridges opened in October 1863, which supplied the besieged federal forces at Chattanooga, Tenn.; the Red Ball Express, a truck convoy system established in France in 1944, which moved approximately 12,000 tons of matériel a day for 82 days to supply the Allied advance during World War II; or the monumental staging of the 1991 gulf war, which the general in charge deemed “the largest logistical move in history.”
headline: The Things They Left Behind: How the U.S. Laid Waste to Southeast Asia
keywords: Books and Literature;Vietnam War;AGENT ORANGE (DEFOLIANT);The Long Reckoning: A Story of War, Peace, and Redemption in Vietnam (Book);Black, George (Author)

abstract: Financial advisers recommend that business owners examine their accounts now to ensure they are protected in case of a future bank failure.

headline: How Small Businesses Can Find Safety Before the Next Bank Crisis
keywords: Small Business;Banking and Financial Institutions;Federal Deposit Insurance Corp;Regulation and Deregulation of Industry;Content Type: Service;Silicon Valley Bank

abstract: On set with the hit mystery series, which, amid all the gore, presents one of the most sensitive portraits of women on TV.
lead_paragraph: In a cabin in the wilderness, a group of starving teenage girls, a teenage boy and one adult man wake to an unfamiliar smell. Their noses twitching in the air, they leave their thin blankets and head out into the snowy wild in socks and insufficient clothes. Outside, their friend, whose body they tried to cremate last night, has turned into smoked meat. They surround her corpse, girl-shaped but foodlike, like a pig from the barbecue pit. One of the girls stands near the charred flesh, knife in hand. “She wants us to,” she says. A few moments later, the feast begins.
headline: ‘Yellowjackets’ Shows Us the Teenage Girlhood We Were Hungry For
keywords: Women and Girls;Television;Teenagers and Adolescence;Yellowjackets (TV Program)

headline: 10 Places to See Wildflowers in the West
keywords: Flowers and Plants;Parks and Other Recreation Areas;National Parks, Monuments and Seashores;Deserts;Travel and Vacations;Spring (Season);Anza-Borrego Desert State Park (Calif);Channel Islands National Park (Calif);CHINO HILLS (CALIF);Malibu (Calif);San Diego (Calif);Ventura (Calif);Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area (Calif);Tucson (Ariz);Phoenix (Ariz)

abstract: As Annie Cohen-Solal shows in “Picasso the Foreigner,” the Spanish master was always under suspicion in France, simply for being not-French.
lead_paragraph: This month’s half-century anniversary of Pablo Picasso’s death (on April 8, 1973) will bring tributes large and small. And a substantial one has already arrived in Annie Cohen-Solal’s “Picasso the Foreigner: An Artist in France, 1900-1973,” an outsize but propulsive read (600 pages in snack-size chapters) with a peppery twofold brief. It’s both a portrait of Picasso, that Zeus of 20th-century modernism, as a cultural outcast, a pariah, and an indictment of the culture — French — that made him one.
headline: Pablo Picasso, the Pariah of Paris
keywords: Books and Literature;Cohen-Solal, Annie;Picasso, Pablo;Art;Paris (France);Content Type: Personal Profile

abstract: A Netflix series dramatizes the efforts of Varian Fry, an American who helped save some 2,000 people from the Nazis without his government’s support.
lead_paragraph: When Anna Winger, the co-creator of the new Netflix series “Transatlantic,” relocated to the vibrant French port city of Marseille last year, she found a dilapidated villa awaiting her. The “relic,” as she called it, was ideal for her purpose: the recreation of the Villa Air-Bel where, early in World War II, a dapper American named Varian Fry oversaw an extraordinary rescue operation for artists and writers, most of them Jews, hounded by the Nazis and the Vichy government of occupied France.
headline: In ‘Transatlantic,’ Stories of Rescue and Resistance From World War II
keywords: Television;Transatlantic (TV Program);World War II (1939-45);Holocaust and the Nazi Era;Rescues;Fry, Varian;Gold, Mary Jayne;Hirschman, Albert O;Jacobs, Gillian;Smith, Cory Michael;Stoll, Corey;Winger, Anna

abstract: This case has reminded us that the justice system is easily exploited in ways that are wasteful and stupid.
lead_paragraph: In what was the second highest profile legal deliberation this week, jurors determined on Thursday that Gwyneth Paltrow was not liable for damages in a ski crash between her and a retired optometrist, Terry Sanderson, causing him, he alleged, a traumatic brain injury. Mr. Sanderson was denied the $300,000 he sued for, and Ms. Paltrow, whose net worth is reportedly north of $200 million, was awarded the amount she requested in a countersuit: $1.
headline: In the Utah Ski Trial, We Are All Gwynnocent

abstract: For starters, don’t send any rent checks until you know exactly who you’re sending them to.
lead_paragraph: Q: I didn’t know that the rent-stabilized building where I live had been sold until I received a text message from an unknown number telling me to pay my rent via Venmo or Zelle. Moments later, a stranger knocked at my door and introduced himself as a representative of the new owner. He refused to disclose the owner’s identity and told me I could mail my check to a post office box if I didn’t want to pay rent digitally. I was left feeling stunned, vulnerable and betrayed by the previous landlord. Was there no obligation to inform tenants that the building had been sold, and to verify the new landlord’s identity on our behalf? Shouldn’t we have received notice?
headline: When the Landlord Sells the Building, What Are Your Rights?
keywords: Real Estate and Housing (Residential);Landlords;Renting and Leasing (Real Estate);Rent Control and Stabilization

abstract: She started an organization whose curriculums challenge teenagers to understand the roots of the Holocaust, racism, apartheid and other human injustices.
lead_paragraph: Margot Stern Strom, a former schoolteacher who in the mid-1970s turned her dismay over her lack of knowledge about the Holocaust into a nonprofit educational organization that develops anti-hate curriculums for teenagers, died on Tuesday at her home in Brookline, Mass. She was 81.
headline: Margot Stern Strom, Anti-Bigotry Educator, Dies at 81
keywords: Strom, Margot Stern;Deaths (Obituaries);Facing History & Ourselves (Nonprofit);Holocaust and the Nazi Era;Education (K-12);History (Academic Subject);Discrimination

abstract: For five years, the French capital has permitted the renting of electric scooters, which have proven both popular and perilous. On Sunday, voters will decide whether to end the experiment.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Manil Hadjoudj was handing out fliers at the entrance to Sorbonne University, tirelessly repeating, “Do you care about electric scooters?” to passing students, most of whom seemed indifferent to his plea.
headline: Green Savior or Deadly Menace? Paris Votes on E-Scooter Ban
keywords: Paris (France);Electric Bicycles, Motorcycles and Scooters;France;Hidalgo, Anne (1959- );LimeBike;Elections;Traffic Accidents and Safety;Local Government;Referendums;Start-ups

abstract: A log of messages shows how agents scrambled after evidence and sought to recruit members of the group all while trying to squeeze in workouts and cope with the bureau’s obsolete technology.
lead_paragraph: In March 2021, two months after the F.B.I. arrested Dominic Pezzola, a New York Proud Boy, on charges stemming from the Capitol attack, one of the lead agents on the case made an unusual confession. On Lync, the bureau’s internal chat system, she said she felt sorry for the man she had helped take into custody.
headline: Inside the F.B.I.’s Jan. 6 Investigation of the Proud Boys
keywords: Proud Boys;Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021);Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right;Federal Bureau of Investigation;Justice Department;Tarrio, Enrique;Nordean, Ethan;Biggs, Joseph (1984- );Pezzola, Dominic;Rehl, Zach;United States Politics and Government

abstract: The Florida governor hasn’t yet swung back hard at Trump.
lead_paragraph: There is a presumption among a certain kind of analyst — rooted, I presume, in a deeply buried belief in the vengeance of Almighty God — that because Republicans morally deserve Donald Trump they will be stuck with him no matter what. That having refused so many opportunities to take a righteous stand against him, they will be condemned to halt at the edge of a post-Trump promised land, gazing pathetically across the Jordan even as they cast in their lots with the False Orange Messiah once again.
headline: What the Trump Indictment Means for Ron DeSantis and the G.O.P.
keywords: United States Politics and Government;Presidential Election of 2024;Politics and Government;DeSantis, Ron;Trump, Donald J;Republican Party;Florida;Campaign Finance;Presidential Election of 2016;Frauds and Swindling;New York State Criminal Case Against Trump (71543-23)

abstract: Across many court cases over the decades, Mr. Trump has regularly leaned on those tactics. Now facing criminal charges in Manhattan, he has already lashed out at the judge.
lead_paragraph: Attack. Attack. Attack.
headline: Donald Trump’s Time-Tested Legal Strategy: Attack and Delay

abstract: South Carolina had fielded the nation’s toughest defense, but couldn’t stop the offensive fireworks of Iowa’s Caitlin Clark.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — As the victories mounted, 42 in a row across two seasons, Coach Dawn Staley acknowledged that while South Carolina did not feel pressure, exactly, it did sense the weight of expectation as it sought a second consecutive women’s N.C.A.A. basketball championship.
headline: How Iowa Ended South Carolina’s Storied Perfect Season
keywords: NCAA Basketball Championships (Women);Basketball (College);University of Iowa;University of South Carolina;Clark, Caitlin (2002- );Boston, Aliyah (2001- );Staley, Dawn;Coaches and Managers

abstract: Donald Trump’s criminal indictment and Fox News’s civil trial have nothing in common, but, combined, they delivered a rare reckoning for two forces that have transformed politics.
lead_paragraph: For the better part of a decade, Donald J. Trump and his allies at Fox News have beguiled some Americans and enraged others as they spun up an alternative world where elections turned on fraud, one political party oppressed another, and one man stood against his detractors to carry his version of truth to an adoring electorate.
headline: Trump and Fox News, Twin Titans of Politics, Hit With Back-to-Back Rebukes
keywords: Fox News Channel;Dominion Voting Systems Corp;Libel and Slander;Suits and Litigation (Civil);Voting Machines;News and News Media;Television;Murdoch, Rupert;Freedom of the Press;Trump, Donald J;Frauds and Swindling;Campaign Finance;United States Politics and Government
